description:
Corallochytrium limacisporum is a species of unicellular marine protist that belongs to the kingdom Chromista. It is classified within the phylum Bigyra, a group of heterotrophic, usually amoeboid or flagellated organisms.

Corallochytrium limacisporum is characterized by its unique morphology and lifestyle. It has a spherical or ellipsoidal cell body that can reach up to 20 micrometers in diameter. The cell is enclosed within a cell wall and contains a single nucleus.

This species is known to reproduce asexually through the formation of sporangia, which are specialized structures that release motile zoospores. The zoospores are equipped with two flagella, allowing them to swim and disperse. After a period of motility, the zoospores settle and develop into new vegetative cells, completing the life cycle.

Corallochytrium limacisporum is found in marine environments, typically associated with coral reefs and other coastal ecosystems. It is believed to play a role in the microbial community dynamics and nutrient cycling within these habitats.

The specific ecological functions and interactions of Corallochytrium limacisporum within the marine ecosystem are still being investigated by researchers to expand our understanding of this unique protist species.
